an important difference between the value a function is approaching—what we call the *limit*—and the value of the function itself. Graphs are a great tool for understanding this difference.\\n\\n[[☃ image 6]]\\n\\nIn the example above, we see that the function value is undefined, but the limit value is approximately $0.25$.\\n\\nJust remember that we're dealing with an approximation, not an exact value. We could zoom in further to get a better approximation if we wanted.\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"image 6\":{\"type\":\"image\",\"alignment\":\"block\",\"static\":false,\"graded\":true,\"options\":{\"static\":false,\"title\":\"\",\"range\":[[0,10],[0,10]],\"box\":[712,594],\"backgroundImage\":{\"url\":\"https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/86075d242765234bf577732aaee4471116e56996.gif\",\"width\":712,\"height\":594},\"labels\":[],\"alt\":\"\",\"caption\":\"[desmos.com](https://www.desmos.com/calculator/nudqcbtd3t) to inspect $\\\\displaystyle{\\\\lim_{x \\\\to 2}{\\\\dfrac{x-2}{x^2-4}}}$\\n\\nNotice how, as we get closer and closer to x=2 from both the left and the right, we seem to approach y=0.25.\"},\"version\":{\"major\":0,\"minor\":0}}}},{\"content\":\"## Examples\\n\\nThe examples below highlight interesting cases of using graphs to approximate limits. Here's a classic example:\\n\\n[[☃ image 1]]\\n\\nIn this example, the limit appears to be $1$ because that's what the $y$-values seem to be approaching as our $x$-values get closer and closer to $0$. It doesn't matter that the function is undefined at $x=0$. The limit still exists.\\n\\nHere's another problem for you to try:\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group 1]]\\n\\n**Reinforcing the key idea:** The function value at $x=-4$ is irrelevant to finding the limit. On the flip side, when the function is defined for some $x$-value, that doesn't mean that the limit necessarily exists.\\n\\nJust like an earlier example, this graph shows the sort of thing that can happen when we're working with piecewise functions. Notice how we're not approaching the same $y$-value from both sides of $x=3$.\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group 1]]\\n\\n*Want more practice? Try [this exercise](/e/two-sided-limits-from-graphs).*\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"graded-group 1\":{\"type\":\"graded-group\",\"alignment\":\"default\",\"static\":false,\"graded\":true,\"options\":{\"title\":\"Problem 4\",\"content\":\"**What is a reasonable estimate for $\\\\displaystyle\\\\lim_{x\\\\to 3}g(x)$?**\\n\\n![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/47e3690ce6316dccce0a839cc369595898567e75)\\n\\n[[☃ radio 1]]\\n\\n\",\"images\":{\"web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/47e3690ce6316dccce0a839cc369595898567e75\":{\"width\":325,\"height\":325}},\"widgets\":{\"radio 1\":{\"type\":\"radio\",\"alignment\":\"default\",\"static\":false,\"graded\":true,\"options\":{\"choices\":[{\"content\":\"$-3$\",\"correct\":false},{\"content\":\"$1$\",\"correct\":false},{\"isNoneOfTheAbove\":false,\"content\":\"$4$\",\"correct\":false},{\"isNoneOfTheAbove\":false,\"content\":\"The limit doesn't exist\",\"correct\":true}],\"randomize\":false,\"multipleSelect\":false,\"countChoices\":false,\"displayCount\":null,\"hasNoneOfTheAbove\":false,\"deselectEnabled\":false},\"version\":{\"major\":1,\"minor\":0}}},\"hint\":{\"content\":\"$\\\\displaystyle \\\\lim_{x\\\\to 3}g(x)$ represents the limit of $g$ as $x$ approaches $3$.\\n\\nWe see that $g(3)=-3$, but that doesn't mean that the limit has the same value!\\n\\nLet's look at the graph and see if the $y$-values seem to approach a distinct value as the $x$-values approach $3$.\\n\\nIf we approach $x=3$ from the left, the $y$-values get closer and closer to $4$. If we approach $x=3$ from the right, the $y$-values get closer and closer to $-3$.\\n\\nThe function does not approach the same value from both directions.\\n\\n![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b73789af81a0ad93d133d964d2c0ccffc08bd773)\\n\\nThe limit $\\\\displaystyle\\\\lim_{x\\\\to 3}g(x)$ doesn't exist.\",\"images\":{\"web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b73789af81a0ad93d133d964d2c0ccffc08bd773\":{\"width\":325,\"height\":325}},\"widgets\":{}}},\"version\":{\"major\":0,\"minor\":0}}}},{\"content\":\"## Graphing calculators are pretty slick these days.\\n\\nGraphing calculators like [Desmos](https://www.desmos.com/) can give you a feel for what's happing to the $y$-values as you get closer and closer to a certain $x$-value. Try using a graphing calculator to estimate these limits:\\n\\n$\\\\begin{align}\\n&\\\\displaystyle{\\\\lim_{x \\\\to 0}{\\\\dfrac{x}{\\\\sin(x)}}}\\n\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\n&\\\\displaystyle{\\\\lim_{x \\\\to 3}{\\\\dfrac{x-3}{x^2-9}}}\\n\\\\end{align}$\\n\\nIn both cases, the function isn't defined at the $x$-value we're approaching, but the limit still exists, and we can estimate it.\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{}},{\"content\":\"##Summary questions\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group 4]]\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group 5]]\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"graded-group 4\":{\"type\":\"graded-group\",\"alignment\":\"default\",\"static\":false,\"graded\":true,\"options\":{\"title\":\"Problem 5\",\"content\":\"**Is it always true that $\\\\displaystyle{\\\\lim_{x \\\\to a}{f(x)}=f(a)}$?**\\n\\n[[☃ radio 1]]\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"radio **exact** value of the limit.\"}],\"randomize\":false,\"multipleSelect\":true,\"countChoices\":false,\"displayCount\":null,\"hasNoneOfTheAbove\":false,\"deselectEnabled\":false},\"version\":{\"major\":1,\"minor\":0}}},\"hint\":{\"content\":\"Even The best we can do is reason about what the $y$-values seem to be approaching as our $x$-values get closer and closer to some number.\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{}}},\"version\":{\"major\":0,\"minor\":0}}}}]","clarifications_enabled":true,"relative_url":"/math/ap-calculus-ab/ab-limits-new/ab-1-3/a/approximating-limit-values-from-a-graph","has_custom_thumbnail":false,"source_language":"en","creation_date":"2018-06-27T20:11:48Z","sha":"58eeab055a598229cb3d0e94ee7f87f58311476d","ka_url":"https://www.khanacademy.org/math/ap-calculus-ab/ab-limits-new/ab-1-3/a/approximating-limit-values-from-a-graph","translated_content":null,"translated_title":"Estimating limit values from graphs","author_key":"ag5zfmtoYW4tYWNhZGVteXIXCxIIVXNlckRhdGEiCVRvbWVyIEdhbAw","translated_description_html":"The best way to start reasoning about limits is using graphs. Learn how we analyze a limit graphically and see cases where a limit doesn&#39;t exist.","do_not_publish":false,"related_content":[],"custom_title_tag":"","edit_slug":"edit/a/xf9fbb880712fbb6f","author_names":[],"translated_html_content":"","listed":true,"alternate_slugs":[],"deleted_mod_time":null,"perseus_content":"[{\"content\":\"There's an important difference between the value a function is approaching—what we call the *limit*—and the value of the function itself. Graphs are a great tool for understanding this difference.\\n\\n[[☃ image 6]]\\n\\nIn the example above, we see that the function value is undefined, but the limit value is approximately $0.25$.\\n\\nJust remember that we're dealing with an approximation, not an exact value. We could zoom in further to get a better approximation if we wanted.\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"image 6\":{\"type\":\"image\",\"alignment\":\"block\",\"static\":false,\"graded\":true,\"options\":{\"static\":false,\"title\":\"\",\"range\":[[0,10],[0,10]],\"box\":[712,594],\"backgroundImage\":{\"url\":\"https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/86075d242765234bf577732aaee4471116e56996.gif\",\"width\":712,\"height\":594},\"labels\":[],\"alt\":\"\",\"caption\":\"[desmos.com](https://www.desmos.com/calculator/nudqcbtd3t) to inspect $\\\\displaystyle{\\\\lim_{x \\\\to 2}{\\\\dfrac{x-2}{x^2-4}}}$\\n\\nNotice how, as we get closer and closer to x=2 from both the left and the right, we seem to approach y=0.25.\"},\"version\":{\"major\":0,\"minor\":0}}}},{\"content\":\"## Examples\\n\\nThe examples below highlight interesting cases of using graphs to approximate limits. In some of the examples, the limit value and the function value are equal, and in other examples, they are not.\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{}},{\"content\":\"### Sometimes the limit value equals the function value.\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group 1]]\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"graded-group But, sometimes the limit value does not equal the function value.\\n\\nWhenever you're dealing with a piecewise function, it's possible to get a graph like the one below.\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group Here's a classic example:\\n\\n[[☃ image 1]]\\n\\nIn this example, the limit appears to be $1$ because that's what the $y$-values seem to be approaching as our $x$-values get closer and closer to $0$. It doesn't matter that the function is undefined at $x=0$. The limit still exists.\\n\\nHere's another problem for you to try:\\n\\n[[☃ graded-group 1]]\\n\\n**Reinforcing the key idea:** The function value at $x=-4$ is irrelevant to finding the limit. All that matters is figuring out what the $y$-values are approaching as we get closer and closer to $x=-4$.\",\"images\":{},\"widgets\":{\"image 1\":{\"type\":\"image\",\"alignment\":\"block\",\"static\":false,\"graded\":true,\"options\":{\"static\":false,\"title\":\"\",\"range\":[[0,10],[0,10]],\"box\":[225,225],\"backgroundImage\":{\"url\":\"web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4ff2cd90f5899f6a1123cd44e64ca0647804a78b\",\"width\":225,\"height\":225},\"labels\":[],\"alt\":\"\",\"caption\":\"This is the graph of y = x / sin(x). happen when we're working with piecewise functions.
